main.java.enigma

Class Rotors

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.java.enigma.Rotors

  • public class Rotors
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains 3-4 instances of the Rotor class. Also acts as the reflector in an Enigma machine. Fully encrypts a character (except for Plugboard Substitutions) and handles the proper cycling of the individual Rotor instances. The rotor options are represented as an integer numbered 0-9. The rotors are mapped as follows: 0 - Rotor I; 1 - Rotor II; 2 - Rotor III; 3 - Rotor IV; 4 - Rotor V; 5 - Rotor VI; 6 - Rotor VII; 7 - Rotor VIII; 9 - Rotor Beta; 10 - Rotor Gamma Reflector options are also represented as an integer. The options are numbered 0-3, and are mapped as follows: 0 - Reflector B; 1 - Reflector C; 2 - Reflector B thin; 3 - Reflector C thin Ring and rotor settings are represented using characters.
    Version:
    0.9 Nov 22, 2013
    Author:
    Bryan Matthew Winstead, Team Enigma

    • Constructor Detail

      • Rotors

        public Rotors(int[] rotorChoices,
      int reflectorChoice)
        Constructor. Accepts an array representing 3-4 Enigma rotor choices, plus an integer indicating the reflector. Ring settings and initial position have to be set separately. The Reflector itself is actually a Rotor that is never rotated.
        Parameters:
        rotorChoices - An array of 3-4 integers numbered 0-9 corresponding to the different rotors in use by the German military
        reflectorChoice - An integer indicating the reflector to be used. Valid options are 0-3.

    • Method Detail

      • setPositions

        public void setPositions(char[] choices)
        Sets the initial starting positions of the rotors.
        Parameters:
        choices - Array of 3-4 characters indicating the starting positions of the rotors. This corresponds to the letters indicated on the top of the Enigma Machine before the operator begins encrypt or decrypt his message.

      • setRingSettings

        public void setRingSettings(char[] choices)
        Sets the initial ring settings of the rotors. This rotates the substitution mapping of the letters.
        Parameters:
        choices - An array of 3-4 letters indicating the ring settings. On the Enigma Machine, these would be adjusted by aligning the indicated letter with a mark on the rotor before the rotor is installed in the Enigma.

      • encrypt

        public char encrypt(char letter)
        Encrypts an individual character. A character is first forwardEncrypted through each rotor in the Enigma, then sent through the reflector (a one-way rotor that does not cycle). Then the character is reverseEncrypted through each rotor before the final character is returned.
        Parameters:
        letter - Character to be encrypted.
        Returns:
        Final character after processing.

      • getPositions

        public char[] getPositions()
        Returns the Rotor Positions to EnigmaMachine, which then passes them on to the GUI
        Returns:
        A 3-4 character array representing the current positions of the Enigma rotors

      • getReflector

        public int getReflector()
        Returns the reflector choice to EnigmaMachine, which then passes where it's needed.
        Returns:
        An integer representing the reflector choice.

      • getRingSettings

        public char[] getRingSettings()
        Returns the ring settings to the EnigmaMachine, which then passes it where it's needed.
        Returns:
        3-4 character array representing the ring settings.
